title: Fundamental Rights (Part III, Articles 12-35)
description: Constitutional guarantees protecting citizens' basic freedoms and rights.

rights.title: Right to Equality
rights.description: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the law within the territory of India.
implications: No discrimination based on caste, religion, sex, or place of birth
Equal access to public facilities and services
examples: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala - Property rights case
Mandal Commission case - Right to reservation
AIIMS v. Shafiq Ahmed - Right to equality in healthcare

rights.title: Prohibition of Discrimination on Grounds of Religion, Race, Caste, Sex or Place of Birth
rights.description: No citizen shall be discriminated against solely on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth.
implications: Government cannot discriminate in public service
Cannot deny entry to public places based on protected characteristics
Cannot restrict access to educational institutions
Exceptions: State can make provisions for SCs, STs, and OBCs
examples: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India - Backward classes reservation
Joseph Shine v. Union of India - Decriminalization case
Bhatnagar v. State of Uttar Pradesh - Religious discrimination

rights.title: Equality of Opportunity in Matters of Public Employment
rights.description: No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in relation to, any employment or office under the State.
implications: Equal opportunity for public sector jobs
Reservation for SCs, STs, OBCs permitted
No religious test for public office
examples: Balaji v. State of Mysore - Reservation eligibility
State of Kerala v. N.M. Thomas - Seniority rules
G. Narayana Rao v. Union of India - Promotion and reservation

rights.title: Protection of Certain Rights Regarding Freedom of Speech, etc.
rights.description: All citizens have the right to freedom of speech and expression, freedom to assemble peacefully, freedom to form associations, freedom to move freely throughout India, freedom to reside and settle, and freedom to practice any profession or trade.
implications: Freedom to form associations or unions
Freedom to practice profession or trade
examples: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras - Freedom of speech
Indian Express v. Union of India - Press freedom
Asha Parekh v. State of Gujarat - Right to peaceful assembly
Hamdard Dawakhana v. Union of India - Right to business

rights.title: Protection of Life and Personal Liberty
rights.description: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
implications: Right to life and personal liberty
Interpreted to include right to dignity, health, education
examples: Menaka Gandhi v. Union of India - Right to life expansion
Muller v. Oregon - Working conditions and life
D.K. Basu v. State of West Bengal - Custodial violence
Virender Gaur v. State - Right to clean environment

rights.title: Protection Against Arrest and Detention
rights.description: No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed of the grounds for arrest, nor shall he be denied the right to consult and to be defended by a legal practitioner.
implications: Right to know grounds of arrest
examples: Ajay Maken v. Union of India - Preventive detention
Sunil Batra v. Delhi Administration - Prison conditions
D.K. Basu v. State of West Bengal - Arrest procedures
S. Varadarajan v. Government of India - Torture prevention

rights.title: Freedom of Religion
rights.description: Subject to public order, morality and health and to the other provisions of this Part, all persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practise and propagate religion.
implications: Subject to public order and morality
examples: Church of God in India v. State of Madras - Religious freedom
Adi Sankaracharya Devasthanams v. State - Temple rights
S.R. Bommai v. Union of India - Secular principles
Roman Catholic Missionary Society v. State - Conversion rights

rights.title: Protection of Interests of Minorities
rights.description: Any section of the citizens residing in the territory of India having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to conserve the same.
examples: Ahmedabad Saint Xavier's Society v. State of Gujarat - Minority institutions
Rev. Sidhajbhai v. State of Gujarat - Minority education
Michael Pallihakkara v. Union of India - Minority rights

title: Directive Principles of State Policy (Part IV, Articles 36-51)
description: Guidelines for state action in framing laws and policies; not directly enforceable but fundamental to governance.

rights.title: State Policy on Health, Education, and Living Standards
rights.description: The State shall direct its policy towards securing adequate means of livelihood for all citizens, free medical aid, compulsory education, and social security.
examples: AIIMS v. Shafiq Ahmed - Right to health
Unni Krishnan v. State of Andhra Pradesh - Right to education
Jacob Mathew v. State of Punjab - Right to medical care

rights.title: Right to Work, Education and Public Assistance
rights.description: The State shall, within the limits of its economic capacity and development, make effective provision for securing the right to work, to education and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness and disablement.
examples: Paschim Banga Khet Mazdoor Samity v. State of West Bengal - Right to work
Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation - Right to livelihood
M.C. Mehta v. Union of India - Environmental rights

rights.title: Duty of State to Provide Free and Compulsory Education
rights.description: The State shall endeavor to provide free and compulsory education to all children until they attain the age of fourteen years.
examples: Unni Krishnan v. State of Andhra Pradesh - Right to free education
J.P. Unangst v. State of Haryana - Educational facilities
M.R. Pasricha School v. Union of India - Right to education

title: Rights of Citizens and Non-Citizens
description: Additional protections and rights available to Indian citizens.

rights.title: Right to Constitutional Remedies
rights.description: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of rights conferred by the Constitution.
implications: Habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto, certiorari
examples: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India - Constitutional remedies
Maruti v. Union of India - Access to justice
People's Union for Democratic Rights v. Union of India - Public interest litigation

rights.title: Right to Constitutional Remedies by High Courts
rights.description: Every High Court shall have the power, throughout its territorial jurisdiction, to issue directions, orders or writs for the enforcement of rights.
examples: S.P. Sampath Kumar v. Union of India - High Court jurisdiction
Ratlam Municipality v. Vardhichand - Environmental remedies
Shiv Sena v. Narendra Rane - Electoral remedies

title: Fundamental Duties (Article 51A)
description: Constitutional obligations of citizens regarding the nation and fellow citizens.

rights.title: Fundamental Duties of Citizens
rights.description: It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to abide by the Constitution, respect its ideals, cherish national symbols, safeguard sovereignty, strive for excellence in education, and protect environment and wildlife.
examples: S. Khushboo v. Kannathasan - Right to express but duty to society
Shruti v. Amrit Banerjee - National solidarity
Res Ipsa Loquitur - Environmental duties
